posts.author: Tyris2222
posts.content:
How would you rate the usefulness of these feats?

Crippling Strike
Defensive Roll
Improved Evasion
Opportunist
Skill Mastery
Slippery Mind
Blinding Speed

posts.author: Maximillian Kane
posts.content:
Hey, mate!

Well, I am not so experienced with Rogues, but I guess most are environment-dependant. BUt let me try to give you a general idea:

- Crippling Strike: VERY GOOD against things that aren't immune to it. It lowers the STR score of the target when it's sneaked. If a lot of immunities are common where you play, not so useful.
- Blinding Speed: OK if there is no perma-haste or other way to haste yourself. Otherwise a wasted investment. a Haste wand or even scrolls are more useful, being that BS is only once-per-day for a short duration.
- Slippery Mind: Useless if you have the habit of carrying Clarity Potions around (which as a rogue you should).
- Defensive Roll: It's a requirement for Epic Dodge, which is the must-have of all dex-oriented builds that have Rogue levels, but the feat itself if not to get ED isn't worth the investment.
- Improved Evasion: It's the other requirement of Epic Dodge, so it's often taken for that. Has some value for STR-oriented rogues because their Reflex save is lower, and that makes them take half damage when they fail a reflex save. For a DEX-heavy build (other than as a requirement for Epic Dodge), it's nearly useless, as Reflex should be a strong save already, so how often will you really fail a Reflex save to make use of this feat? Answer, probably 5% of the time (when you roll a natural 1).
- Opportunist: Not totally worthless if you have NOTHING ELSE to invest on, but I would take Improved Sneak Attack over it anytime.
- Skill Mastery: Can be useful to set traps in combat, but how often do you do that? If your set trap is high enough, you probably won't need it.

As for the feats you asked about, these are all, but if you take Rogue levels in epics, you'll have access to other feats. Here is a list:

- Improved Sneak Attack: Gives you an extra d6 of SA damage, which is good.
- Epic Skill Focus: Gives you +10 to one skill and can be taken multiple times (applying to different skills). So you can have ESF: Set Traps and set traps in combat without skill mastery, for example, or you can have ESF: Hide and ESF: Move Silently if your world has a nerfed True Seeing spell, etc...

Most of the stuff is dependant on where you play, but I hope this helps you a bit.

Take it EZ!
